Intervention.evidence: Isolated mouse (wild-type, sensitive regulatory subunit 1 [−/−], and cardiac knockout renal outer medullary potassium) hearts were given cardioplegia ± diazoxide (N = 9-16 each) before global ischemia (90 minutes) and 30 minutes reperfusion.

Objective.evidence: We hypothesized that pharmacologic blockade or genetic deletion (knockout) of renal outer medullary potassium and sensitive regulatory subunit 1 would result in loss of diazoxide cardioprotection in models of global ischemia with cardioplegia.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Left ventricular pressures were compared before and after ischemia.

Result_Outcome.evidence: In isolated hearts, diazoxide improved left ventricular function after prolonged ischemia compared with cardioplegia alone in wild-type and knockout (sensitive regulatory subunit 1 [−/−] and cardiac knockout renal outer medullary potassium) mice.
